From Wiktionary, the free dictionary
See also: platte and Plätte

English

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Borrowed from German Platte.

Proper noun

[edit]

Platte (plural Plattes)

  1. A surname from German.

Derived terms

[edit]
  • North Platte
  • Platteville
  • Plattsmouth

Statistics

[edit]
  • According to the 2010 United States Census, Platte is the 21986th most common surname in the United States, belonging to 1180 individuals. Platte is most common among White (95.42%) individuals.

Further reading

[edit]
  • Hanks, Patrick, editor (2003), “Platte”, in Dictionary of American Family Names, volume 3, New York: Oxford University Press, →ISBN.

German

[edit]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ˈplatə/, [ˈpla.tə], (southern also) [-te], [-tɛ], (chiefly Switzerland also) [ˈplat.tə]
  • Audio (Germany (Berlin)):(file)
  • Audio (Austria):(file)
  • Rhymes: -atə

Etymology 1

[edit]

From Middle High German platte, from Old High German platta (ca. 900), from Vulgar Latin *platta, *plattus, from Ancient Greek πλατύς (platús, “wide; flat”). Doublet of Plätte and Pläte.

Noun

[edit]

Platte f (genitive Platte, plural Platten)

  1. flat, thin, regularly (not necessarily circular) shaped object
  2. A flat, fairly large serving plate, or (by extension) the food served on it.
  3. Various short forms:
    1. (informal, computing) clipping of Festplatte (“hard disk”)
    3. (music) clipping of Schallplatte (“vinyl record, gramophone record”)
    4. (photography) clipping of Fotoplatte (“photographic plate”)
    5. (printing) clipping of Druckplatte (“printing plate”)
    6. clipping of Grabplatte (“flat gravestone”)
    7. clipping of Tischplatte (“tabletop”)
    8. clipping of Herdplatte (“stovetop”)
    9. (chiefly East Germany) clipping of Plattenbau (“prefab apartment building”)
  4. (geology) tectonic plate
  5. (climbing) smooth rock with no hand- or footholds
  6. (numismatics) planchet
  7. (parts of northern and central Germany) alternative form of Pläte (“bald head”)
Declension
[edit]
Declension of Platte [feminine]
singular plural
indef. def. noun def. noun
nominative eine die Platte die Platten
genitive einer der Platte der Platten
dative einer der Platte den Platten
accusative eine die Platte die Platten

Descendants
[edit]
  • → Czech: plát
  • → Kashubian: plata

Etymology 2

[edit]

From Rotwelsch platt machen, platte machen (“to spend the night outside”), originally “to flee outside”, from Yiddish מאַכן פּליטה (makhn pleyte, “to escape, run away”). פּליטה (pleyte) is from Hebrew פְּלֵטָה (pəlēṭā, “remainder, survivors”). Doublet of Pleite.

A user suggests that this German entry be cleaned up, giving the reason: “Where or in what register is this used?”.
Please see the discussion on Requests for cleanup(+) for more information and remove this template after the problem has been dealt with.

Noun

[edit]

Platte f (genitive Platte, plural Platten)

  1. bivouac; overnight camp
  2. A fixed outdoor sleeping place of a person or people of a nomadic group.
  3. (Austria, Vienna, archaic) gang (criminal gang)
Declension
[edit]
Declension of Platte [feminine]
singular plural
indef. def. noun def. noun

dative einer der Platte den Platten
accusative eine die Platte die Platten

Hunsrik

[edit]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ˈplatə/
  • Rhymes: -atə
  • Syllabification: Plat‧te

Noun

[edit]

Platte f

  1. plural of Platt
